articles.description:
A vaccine to tackle a future pandemic could be available in GP practices just four months after the threat is identified, according to NHS planning assumptions. NHS England has this week published a new ‘framework’ for managing the response to any future pandemic, which covered the role of primary care and digital technologies.  On vaccines,
The post GPs could vaccinate people four months into future pandemic, says NHSE appeared first on Pulse Today.
articles.title: GPs could vaccinate people four months into future pandemic, says NHSE

articles.author: Mollie Fraser-Andrews
articles.description:
In the latest of a new monthly series, our clinical adviser Dr Keith Hopcroft is asking readers to guess what abnormality was shown on the blood tests of a 73-year-old man with stage 3 CKD. Submit your answers below the line! You see a 73-year-old man for a follow-up appointment. He was previously seen by
The post Case of the month: What is the abnormality in this elderly man’s blood tests? appeared first on Pulse Today.
articles.title: Case of the month: What is the abnormality in this elderly man’s blood tests?

articles.author: Eliza Parr
articles.description:
NICE has recommended a new digital tool which could speed up ADHD diagnoses and help clinicians rule out more cases. In draft guidance published today, NICE approved NHS use of the computer-based QbTest, alongside a standard clinical assessment, for diagnosis of attention deficit hyperactivity disorder (ADHD) in children and young people. QbTest tracks the movement
The post NICE recommends digital test for ADHD to help speed up diagnosis appeared first on Pulse Today.
articles.title: NICE recommends digital test for ADHD to help speed up diagnosis

articles.author: Anna Colivicchi
articles.description:
The CQC ‘got things wrong’ in the implementation of its new regulatory approach, its chief has admitted, while announcing an increase to inspections. Interim chief executive Kate Terroni wrote to providers yesterday to say that the new system has ‘made things more difficult than they should be’, and announced that the CQC ‘will increase the
The post CQC plans more inspections after admitting botched rollout of new regime appeared first on Pulse Today.
articles.title: CQC plans more inspections after admitting botched rollout of new regime

articles.author: Eliza Parr
articles.description:
The Liberal Democrats have called for a ‘new legal right’ to see a GP within a week ahead of the King’s Speech. On Wednesday, the King will lay out the new Government’s legislative agenda for the coming months including the bills it will introduce to Parliament. More than 35 bills are expected over the parliamentary
The post Lib Dems ask Government to include GP waits in King’s Speech appeared first on Pulse Today.
articles.title: Lib Dems ask Government to include GP waits in King’s Speech

articles.author: Maya Dhillon
articles.description:
Copperfield offers suggestions to Lord Darzi for his investigation into the state of the NHS Amazing what you can do in six weeks, isn’t it? It’s taken 76 years to destroy the NHS, but Lord Darzi is only going to need a month and a half to stick it all back together again. That’s how
The post Darzi could send ARRS to the dogs appeared first on Pulse Today.
articles.title: Darzi could send ARRS to the dogs

articles.author: Eliza Parr
articles.description:
Doctors should reduce ‘unnecessary’ prescribing and blood testing to help tackle the climate crisis, according to a royal college. A new ‘green toolkit’, produced by the Royal College of Physicians (RCP), suggests a range of actions doctors can take to ‘help mitigate and adapt to the impacts of climate change’.  The royal college argued that
The post Doctors advised to reduce prescribing and testing to tackle climate change appeared first on Pulse Today.
articles.title: Doctors advised to reduce prescribing and testing to tackle climate change

articles.author: Eliza Parr
articles.description:
Wes Streeting is ‘defending’ the previous Conservative Government’s ban on private prescribing of puberty blockers.  The emergency ban, brought in by former health secretary Victoria Atkins in May, is currently being challenged at the High Court by transgender rights activists. But the new Government is defending the decision and is understood to be planning on
The post Streeting ‘defends’ previous Government ban on puberty blockers appeared first on Pulse Today.
articles.title: Streeting ‘defends’ previous Government ban on puberty blockers

articles.author: Eliza Parr
articles.description:
A solicitor has been fined £15,000 by a disciplinary tribunal for ‘improperly threatening’ legal proceedings against a GP practice over Covid-19 vaccine exemptions. Philip Julian Paul Hyland faced two allegations at the recent three-day hearing, all of which the Solicitors Disciplinary Tribunal (SDT) found proved, according to the Law Society Gazette. Mr Hyland had been
The post Solicitor fined £15k by tribunal for ‘threatening’ GP practices appeared first on Pulse Today.
articles.title: Solicitor fined £15k by tribunal for ‘threatening’ GP practices

articles.author: Eliza Parr
articles.description:
Stephen Kinnock will cover general practice in his new minister for care role, the Department of Health and Social Care has said. The Labour MP for Aberafan Maesteg in Wales was appointed as Minister of State for Care early last week, and his official portfolio was published on Friday.  Working under health secretary Wes Streeting,
The post Stephen Kinnock named minister responsible for general practice appeared first on Pulse Today.
articles.title: Stephen Kinnock named minister responsible for general practice

articles.description: Practices that join test sites piloting new models of general practice could be 'unable to opt-out of the PCN DES' for several years even if it becomes far more onerous, the BMA has warned.
articles.title: New GP model pilots could trap practices in PCN DES, says BMA

articles.description: Advice and guidance is effectively 'shifting outpatients onto general practice' and should be commissioned as a multi-million pound directed enhanced service, the BMA England GP committee chair has suggested.
articles.title: Advice and guidance should be a DES worth millions to general practice, says BMA GP chair

articles.description: A GP who forked out £40,000 of her own money to stop her practice being handed to another provider should be fully reimbursed by the NHS, a campaigner has said.
articles.title: GP who spent £40,000 to save her practice 'deserves refund'

articles.description: A GP who forked out £40,000 of her own money to stop her practice being handed to another provider should be fully reimbursed by the NHS, a campaigner has said.
articles.title: GP who spent £40,000 to save her practice 'deserves NHS refund'

articles.description: More than 10,000 cases of whooping cough have been recorded in the first six months of 2024 as cases remain far higher that at any point in the past decade.
articles.title: Whooping cough cases reach more than 10,000 in first half of 2024

articles.description: More than three quarters of the British public are concerned about the level of pressure on general practice, according to polling carried out just before the general election.
articles.title: Vast majority of public concerned about pressure on GPs, poll shows

articles.description: Practices should consider whether home visits or being in consultation rooms alone with patients is safe and encourage staff to travel together amid racist rioting that has spread across the UK, BMA GP leaders have warned in a letter to the profession.
articles.title: GP leaders condemn racist riots and urge home visit safety review

articles.description: Nearly a third of GPs cut their contracted working hours in 2023 as the profession remained more overworked and less satisfied than any other group of doctors, a GMC report shows.
articles.title: GPs forced to cut working hours as overwork and low satisfaction take toll, GMC reveals

articles.description: GP practices across the country are closing earlier to ensure the safety of staff and patients as racist and Islamophobic riots continue to spread across the country.
articles.title: NHS spells out support for GPs as riots put pressure on general practice

articles.description: GPs are more than twice as likely to work full-time hours as official data suggest, according to research that calls for sessions to be scrapped as a measure of family doctors' work commitment.
articles.title: Official data massively underrepresent full-time working in general practice, research shows

articles.description: LMCs have condemned far-right racist and Islamophobic rioting and have released guidelines on what practices can do to protect staff and patients.
articles.title: LMCs condemn far-right riots and urge practices to consider steps to keep staff safe

articles.description: Scottish GP and TV doctor Dr Punam Krishan has been announced as one of the celebrity contestants on this year's series of Strictly Come Dancing.
articles.title: GP to take part in this year's Strictly Come Dancing

articles.description: BMA England GP committee chair Dr Katie Bramall-Stainer explains why GPs need to take collective action, what she hopes it will achieve and the changes that are needed to ensure a sustainable future for general practice.
articles.title: Podcast: Dr Katie Bramall-Stainer on GP collective action and what happens now

articles.description: GPs are being urged to join hundreds of people who have signed an open letter to the senior doctor leading a rapid government review of the NHS, to highlight facts about the crisis facing general practice.
articles.title: GPs urged to sign letter highlighting pressure on practices amid Darzi review

articles.description: GP practices have been advised to move to remote delivery of appointments while racist and Islamophobic rioting continues across the UK, amid 'very high' levels of fear that have left staff frightened to come to work or deliver home visits.
articles.title: GP practices move to remote appointments as racist riots spark safety fears

articles.description: BMA negotiators could push for an improved retainer scheme and fully-funded fellowships for newly-qualified GPs in next year's contract to build a permanent solution to GP unemployment, England's GP committee chair has suggested.
articles.title: BMA to push for expanded GP retainer and fellowship schemes in next year's contract

articles.description: More than half of GP practices in England took part in clinical research last year - with more than 270,000 patients recruited to studies via primary care, data from the National Institute for Health and Care Research (NIHR) show.
articles.title: More than half of GP practices in England took part in clinical research last year

articles.description: One in three patients who completed an NHS 'soup and shake' weight loss programme put their type 2 diabetes into remission in a year, a major study has found.
articles.title: GP 'soup and shake' referrals put type 2 diabetes in remission for one in three patients

articles.description: GPs and practice staff have reported being targeted with abuse and violence in the ongoing wave of far-right civil unrest and rioting, the RCGP has warned.
articles.title: GPs report being targeted with abuse and violence amid racist rioting

articles.description: GP practices across England have begun to warn patients of the impact on services as they take part in collective action, explaining they are on patients' side and determined to secure better funding for general practice.
articles.title: GP practices begin collective action and warn patients of impact on services

articles.description: Collective action will be 'painful', but adopting safe working limits and pushing back against unfunded work can help practices retain GPs and ultimately lead to improved patient satisfaction, the BMA England GP committee chair has said.
articles.title: Collective action can stop GP burnout and make patients happier, says GP committee chair

articles.description: The extra £82m that is to be added to the additional roles reimbursement scheme (ARRS) to allow PCNs to recruit GPs will be available from October, NHS England has confirmed.
articles.title: GP ARRS plan to start from October, NHS officials confirm

articles.description: Plans to recruit GPs through the additional roles reimbursement scheme (ARRS) could be a first step towards an entirely salaried model of general practice, a prominent GP has warned.
articles.title: Hiring GPs through ARRS 'first step towards entirely salaried model'

articles.description: Frontline NHS staff will continue to be offered COVID-19 jabs as part of this year's autumn vaccination campaign despite updated advice from expert advisers backing a more limited rollout.
articles.title: COVID-19 jabs for NHS staff to continue this autumn despite reduced campaign

articles.description: Talking General Practice speaks to Dr Adrian Hayter, the Royal College of GPs medical director of clinical policy and a GP in Windsor, about the college’s new clinical priority - preventive medicine.
articles.title: Podcast: Preventive medicine in general practice - with Dr Adrian Hayter from the RCGP

articles.description: Backing a 6% pay uplift and plans to recruit 1,000 GPs by expanding the additional roles reimbursement scheme (ARRS) are 'simply the first steps' towards a more sustainable future for general practice, the health and social care secretary has said.

articles.description: GPs are right to press ahead with collective action because plans to create GP jobs through the ARRS are only 'superficially attractive' and the 6% contract uplift is 'not enough', a Rebuild General Practice campaigner has warned.

articles.description: An £82m bolt-on to the additional roles reimbursement scheme (ARRS) unveiled by the government may not deliver the 'more than 1,000' new GP jobs it claims unless recruits are paid below market rates, a specialist accountant has warned.

articles.description: GPonline looks at the steps practices are being asked to take now that the profession in England has voted in favour of collective action.

articles.description: GP partners have voted overwhelmingly in favour of collective action in a landmark BMA ballot that could see widespread adoption of safe working advice including capping daily appointments per GP in the coming days and weeks.

articles.description: More than 1,000 GP jobs will be created in 2024/25 through an £82m expansion of the additional roles reimbursement scheme (ARRS), the government has said, in an emergency intervention to tackle the 'absurd' GP unemployment crisis.

articles.description: More than 1,000 GP jobs will be created in 2024/25 through an £82m expansion of the additional roles reimbursement scheme (ARRS), after the government announced an emergency intervention to tackle the 'absurd' GP unemployment crisis.

articles.description: GPs are by no means guaranteed to see the 6% uplift promised by the government reflected in their pay packets, financial experts have warned.

articles.description: The GMC has warned doctors taking part in protests or activism of their duty to 'follow the law', in updated guidance that sets out how the regulator will approach cases where doctors receive a criminal conviction.

articles.description: A major private provider of NHS GP services will not have its practice contracts terminated despite a 'serious breach' of their terms, an ICB has confirmed.

articles.description: The BMA is recommending junior doctors accept a new offer that would see them receive an average 22.3% pay increase over two years.

articles.description: Any upcoming assessments of GP practices will take into consideration the global IT outage that affected EMIS, the CQC has confirmed.

articles.description: The shingles vaccine introduced in the NHS from last summer offers significant protection against dementia, a major study suggests.

articles.description: NHS targets for increasing the UK medical workforce risk failure because half of medical trainers are at high or moderate risk of burnout, the latest GMC national training survey warns.

articles.description: Online consultation tools used in general practice can put patients at risk and should be investigated by NHS England, a health watchdog has warned.

articles.description: Patients must always be offered a clear choice to see a fully-qualified GP rather than a physician associate, a health watchdog has warned, after polling showed only half understand the difference.

articles.title: Podcast: Gambling harms - how GPs and practices can help their patients

articles.description: Doctors should reduce unnecessary prescribing and only request blood tests if they are essential to help tackle the climate crisis, according to a new toolkit from the Royal College of Physicians.

articles.description: Practices should set up waiting lists based on clinical need for routine appointments to help manage demand, the BMA has said.
articles.title: BMA recommends practices set up waiting lists for routine appointments

articles.title: Three-quarters of Welsh GPs prepared to take industrial action, BMA poll finds

articles.description: Almost one in 10 GPs believe the practice where they work is at risk of closure within the next 12 months – and over a third know of practices in their area at risk – a GPonline poll has found.
articles.title: One in 10 GPs say their practice is at risk of closure

articles.title: CQC apologises over problems with its new regulation system

articles.description:
WHO has today issued an invitation for manufacturers of mpox vaccines to submit an Expression of Interest for Emergency Use Listing (EUL).
The WHO Director-General announced on 7 August 2024 that he had triggered the process for EUL of mpox vaccines given worrying trends in the disease’s spread. There is a serious and growing outbreak in the Democratic Republic of the Congo (DRC) that has now expanded outside the country. A new viral strain, which first emerged in September 2023, has for the first time been detected outside DRC.
The EUL procedure is an emergency use authorization process, specifically developed to expedite the availability of unlicensed medical products like vaccines that are needed in public health emergency situations. This is a time-limited recommendation, based on a risk-benefit approach.
WHO is requesting manufacturers to submit data to ensure that the vaccines are safe, effective, of assured quality and suitable for the target populations.
Granting of an EUL will accelerate vaccine access particularly for those lower-income countries which have not yet issued their own national regulatory approval. The EUL also enables partners including Gavi and UNICEF to procure vaccines for distribution.
Mpox is a viral illness caused by the monkeypox virus, a species of the genus Orthopoxvirus. Mpox can be transmitted to humans through physical contact with someone who is infectious, with contaminated materials, or with infected animals. 
There are currently two vaccines in use against the disease, both of which have been recommended for use by the WHO Strategic Advisory Group of Experts on Immunization, or SAGE.
articles.title: WHO invites mpox vaccine manufacturers to submit dossiers for emergency evaluation

articles.description:
In the last 12 years, the number of infants under six months of age globally who are exclusively breastfed has increased by more than 10%. This means 48% of infants worldwide now benefit from this healthy start in life. It translates to hundreds of thousands of babies whose lives have been saved by breastfeeding.

While this significant leap brings us closer to the World Health Organization target of increasing exclusive breastfeeding to at least 50% by 2025, there are persistent challenges that must be addressed.

When mothers receive the support they need to breastfeed their babies, everyone benefits. Improving breastfeeding rates could save over 820 000 children’s lives each year, according to the latest available data. 
During this critical period of early growth and development, the a…
articles.title: On World Breastfeeding Week, UNICEF and WHO call for equal access to breastfeeding support

articles.description: The WHO-India donor agreement is part of a US$ 250 million investment from India in support of the establishment of the WHO Global Centre of Traditional Medicine in 2022, which includes financial support for the workplan of the Centre, interim premises and a new building. This support will scale up WHO’s capacities on traditional medicine across technical divisions and regions in the spirit of global collaboration and solidarity. Part of this substantial contribution from the Government of India will also be included in WHO’s Investment Round to resource WHO’s core work during 2025–2028.
articles.title: India commits US$ 85 million to WHO Global Traditional Medicine Centre

articles.description:
Today, 85 sick and severely injured patients from Gaza were evacuated to Abu Dhabi, United Arab Emirates (UAE), for specialized care. This extremely complex joint evacuation was supported by the the World Health Organization (WHO) in partnership with the Government of the UAE and other partners. This is the largest medical evacuation outside Gaza since October 2023.

“I am immensely grateful to the United Arab Emirates for evacuating sick and severely injured patients from Gaza and providing them with lifesaving medical care,” said Dr Hanan Balkhy, WHO Regional Director for the Eastern Mediterranean. “This initiative is a clear demonstration of the intra-regional solidarity that is urgently needed. Support to people in the Region must start from the Region. Thousands more inside Gaza remai…
articles.title: WHO and United Arab Emirates evacuate 85 patients from Gaza

articles.description:
Among adolescent girls who have been in a relationship, nearly a quarter (24%) – close to 19 million – will have experienced physical and/or sexual intimate partner violence by the time they turn 20 years old, as highlighted by a new analysis from the World Health Organization (WHO) published today in The Lancet Child & Adolescent Health. Almost 1 in 6 (16%) experienced such violence in the past year. 
“Intimate partner violence is starting alarmingly early for millions of young women around the world,” said Dr Pascale Allotey, Director of WHO’s Sexual and Reproductive Health and Research Department. “Given that violence during these critical formative years can cause profound and lasting harms, it needs to be taken more seriously as a public health issue – with a focus on prevention and t…
articles.title: Adolescent girls face alarming rates of intimate partner violence

articles.description:
A new project aiming to accelerate the development and accessibility of human avian influenza (H5N1) messenger RNA (mRNA) vaccine candidates for manufacturers in low- and middle-income countries has been launched today. The Argentinian manufacturer Sinergium Biotech will lead this effort leveraging the World Health Organization (WHO) and the Medicines Patent Pool (MPP) mRNA Technology Transfer Programme.
The mRNA Technology Transfer Programme, jointly developed by WHO and MPP, was launched in July 2021 with the aim to build capacity in low- and middle-income countries (LMICs) for the development and production of mRNA-based vaccines. Sinergium Biotech, a partner in the mRNA Technology Transfer Programme, has developed candidate H5N1 vaccines and aims to establish proof-of-concept in precli…
articles.title: New initiative launched to advance mRNA vaccine development against human avian influenza (H5N1)

articles.description:
Sixteen people from Gaza with complicated medical conditions will arrive in Spain today to receive care there, through an evacuation process involving the World Health Organization (WHO) and multiple partners. Fifteen of them are children, ranging in age from 3 to 17 years old. The mother of one of the children will also be treated in Spain. The patients had been in hospital in Egypt for the past several months, after evacuating from Gaza. They are a small portion of the thousands of other children and adults who need access to specialized medical care outside of Gaza. 

“These very sick children will be getting the care they need thanks to cooperation between several partners and countries,” said Dr Tedros Adhanom Ghebreyesus, WHO Director-General. “We are immensely grateful for the suppo…
articles.title: Fifteen children from Gaza to receive urgent medical care in Spain

articles.description: Around 733 million people faced hunger in 2023, equivalent to one in eleven people globally and one in five in Africa, according to the latest State of Food Security and Nutrition in the World (SOFI) report published today by five United Nations specialized agencies.
articles.title: Hunger numbers stubbornly high for three consecutive years as global crises deepen: UN report

articles.description: Despite progress made in reducing HIV infections and AIDS-related deaths among children, a new report released today by the Global Alliance for Ending AIDS in Children by 2030 shows that an urgent scale up of HIV services in countries worst affected by the pandemic is required to end AIDS by 2030.
articles.title: Unfinished business: only the urgent and accelerated delivery of HIV services will keep the promise of ending AIDS in children by 2030

articles.description:
Joint statement by UNICEF Executive Director, Catherine Russell, UNFPA Executive Director, Natalia Kanem, WHO Director-General, Dr Tedros Adhanom Ghebreyesus, UN Women Executive Director, Sima Bahous, and UN High Commissioner for Human Rights, Volker Türk  
“Following the vote today by the National Assembly of The Gambia, we commend the country’s decision to uphold the ban on Female Genital Mutilation (FGM), reaffirming its commitments to human rights, gender equality, and protecting the health and well-being of girls and women. 
“FGM involves cutting or removing some or all of the external female genitalia. Mostly carried out on infants and young girls, it can inflict severe immediate and long-term physical and psychological damage, including infection, later childbearing complications, a…
articles.title: The Gambia’s decision to uphold ban on FGM critical win for girls’ and women’s rights

articles.description:
Global childhood immunization coverage stalled in 2023, leaving 2.7 million additional children un- and under-vaccinated compared to pre-pandemic levels in 2019, according to data published today by the World Health Organization (WHO) and UNICEF.
The latest WHO and UNICEF estimates of national immunization coverage (WUENIC) – which provide the world’s largest and most comprehensive dataset on immunization trends for vaccinations against 14 diseases – underscore the need for ongoing catch-up, recovery and system-strengthening efforts.
“The latest trends demonstrate that many countries continue to miss far too many children,” said UNICEF Executive Director Catherine Russell. “Closing the immunization gap requires a global effort, with governments, partners, and local leaders investing in pri…
articles.title: Global childhood immunization levels stalled in 2023, leaving many without life-saving protection
